questions.question_text:
A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the mass of an object.

(a) The student suspends a mass m = 100 g from the spring. She measures, and records in Table 1.1, the stretched length l of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1.

Describe two techniques for measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram.

She repeats step (a) for values of m = 200 g, m = 300 g, m = 400 g and m = 500 g. Her readings are shown in Table 1.1.

Plot a graph of l / cm (y-axis) against m / g (x-axis). Start the axes from the origin (0, 0). Draw a best-fit straight line. The line might not go through the origin.

Use your graph to determine the length l₀ of the spring with no load on it.

l₀ = .......... cm

An object X is suspended from the spring.

(i) On Fig. 1.2, measure the stretched length lₓ of the spring.

lₓ = ..........

Use the graph and your reading from (d)(i) to determine the mass mₓ of object X. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained your answer.

mₓ = .......... g

Two students measure the mass of another object using the same method and apparatus.

One student records the mass as 132.6 g. The other student records the mass as 130 g.

State and explain which answer has the more suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.
Define acceleration.
Show that the maximum speed of the train is approximately 56 m / s.
Calculate the time taken for the train to reach its maximum speed.
The train has a total mass of 440 000 kg. Calculate the force which causes the acceleration of the train.
The train travels into a headwind. The force of this headwind opposes the motion of the train. State and explain the effect of this force on the motion of the train.
Calculate the spring constant k of the spring.

A student states that the spring has not reached the limit of proportionality when a force of 4500 N is applied to it.

State how the graph shows that this statement is true.

Springs can be compressed by forces. The spring described by Fig. 1.1 is compressed by a force F and has an extension of –0.025 m.

Determine F.
State whether force is a scalar quantity or a vector quantity. Explain your answer.
State the momentum of trolley B before the collision. Explain your answer.

After the collision, the two trolleys are joined together and travel with a constant velocity v = 0.18 m / s to the right. The mass of trolley A is 0.75 kg.

Calculate the mass of trolley B.

The trolleys move onto a rough surface which exerts a constant force F on the trolleys and brings them to rest in 2.6 s.

Calculate F.
A different rough surface exerts a smaller resistive force on the trolleys. State how this affects the time taken to bring the trolleys to rest. Explain your answer.

Plan an experiment which will enable a student to compare the effect of different angles of slope on the average speed of a trolley between points on a ramp. Average speed can be calculated from the equation: average speed = distance / time.

The apparatus available includes:
• a long ramp with a support that enables it to be set at different angles of slope
• a small trolley.

In your plan:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• explain briefly how to do the experiment, including how to take the measurements so that the average speed can be determined
• suggest a possible source of inaccuracy even if the method is carried out carefully
• state the key variables to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.

You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

A student investigates the period of a pendulum. The student adjusts the length of the pendulum to 90.0 cm. He measures the time t for 10 complete oscillations. Calculate the period T of the pendulum. Calculate T².
The student repeats the procedure for d = 45.0 cm. Calculate the period T of the pendulum and T².
Complete the column headings in Table 1.1.
Explain why timing 10 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period T than timing 1 oscillation.
Describe one technique that you use to improve accuracy when measuring the distance d.
Describe one technique that you use to improve accuracy when measuring the time t for 10 oscillations.
The pendulum support is 40 cm above the bench. Estimate the distance x between the bottom of the pendulum support and the floor.
A student plans to plot a graph of T² against d. Suggest suitable values of d that the student can use to obtain measurements that are sufficient for this task.
Using Fig. 7.1, calculate the clockwise moment of the weight of the wooden barrier arm about the pivot.

The wooden barrier arm is in equilibrium. The mass of the soft iron bar A is 23 kg.
Calculate the distance d between the pivot and the joint holding the soft iron bar A.
State and explain what happens to the wooden barrier arm when the switch in the coil circuit is closed.

The switch is opened. An operator decreases the potential difference across the coil and the switch is closed.
State and explain how the effect on the wooden barrier arm compares with the effect in (b)(i).
A student suggests that the soft iron bar A is replaced by a steel bar. Explain why a steel bar is less effective than a soft iron bar in the barrier.
Describe an experiment to determine the spring constant of a spring. Include apparatus, measurements, and calculation. Diagram optional.
Define ‘limit of proportionality’.
Calculate the extension of each spring for a weight of 120 N given spring constants Q = 7.8 N/cm, R = 1.1 N/cm.
State and explain which spring (Q or R) would be more suitable for the baby bouncer shown in Fig. 2.1.
State the difference between a scalar quantity and a vector quantity.
Define momentum.
A test car crashes into a barrier. Mass = 950 kg. Resultant force during crash = 27 000 N. Time to stop = 1.5 s. Calculate the initial velocity of the car.
On Fig. 1.2, sketch a speed–time graph to show the motion of the car from time t = 0 until it stops.
Define momentum.

The golf club is in contact with the ball for 5.0 × 10^–4 s. The velocity of the golf ball as it leaves the golf club is 41 m/s. The golf ball has a mass of 0.046 kg.
(i) Calculate the impulse on the golf ball.
Calculate the force applied to the ball by the golf club.

A rocket has an initial mass of 7.4 × 10^6 kg.
(i) Calculate the initial weight of the rocket.
Define, in words, the term weight.

Describe the motion of the rocket:
From O to A
From A to B
Draw a tangent to the graph at time = 400 s and use this to calculate the acceleration of the rocket at this time. Show your working.
Explain in terms of forces why the rocket reaches terminal velocity as it travels through the atmosphere back to the Earth.
Define the moment of a force and describe the effect that it measures.
Explain what is meant by centre of gravity.
The weight of the block is 1.3 × 10⁷ N. Calculate the moment of the weight of the block about corner X.
State the two different conditions that apply when an object is in equilibrium.
Calculate the maximum momentum of the drag car during the race.
State the feature of Fig. 2.2 that represents the distance travelled by the car.
Determine the distance travelled by the car in the first 6.5 s.
Describe how Fig. 2.2 shows that, after 6.5 s, the car decelerates.
Describe how Fig. 2.2 shows that the deceleration of the car is not constant.
Describe the energy transfer that takes place as the car slows down.

Using Fig. 1.2, determine the reading on the metre ruler when:
1. no weight is attached to the spring
2. a weight of 5.6 N is attached to the spring
Calculate the extension of the spring when the weight attached is 5.6 N.
Using the values found in (a), calculate the spring constant of the spring.
An object of mass 0.50 kg is attached to the spring. Calculate the weight of the object.
The object is pulled downwards until the tension in the spring is 6.5 N. The object is released. Calculate the acceleration of the object immediately after it is released.

The diagram shows three forces acting on an object.
What is the magnitude of the resultant force acting on the object?
A 2.0 N B 10 N C 14 N D 16 N
Which row defines speed and velocity?

The graph shows the journey of a motorcyclist.
Which section of the graph shows the time when the motorcyclist is stationary at some traffic lights?

The acceleration of free fall on the Moon is one sixth of its value on Earth.
On Earth, an astronaut’s mass is measured as 60 kg.
Which row gives the mass and weight of the astronaut on Earth and on the Moon?

The load–extension graph for a material is shown.
Which point indicates the limit of proportionality?

An object of mass 4.0 kg is moving with a velocity of 3.0 m/s in a straight line.
What is the momentum of the object?

A tall cylinder is partly filled with two liquids that do not mix. The liquids have different densities.
A student measures the pressure due to the liquids at different depths.
Which graph shows how the liquid pressure varies between positions P and Q?

A tennis ball with momentum 2.3 kg m/s is struck by a tennis racket.
The racket causes the direction of motion to reverse. The racket exerts an average force of 1500 N for 0.0024 s.
What is the magnitude of the momentum of the ball as it leaves the racket?

A car is travelling at a speed of 8.0 m/s.
The kinetic energy stored in the car is 32 000 J.
What is the kinetic energy stored when its speed increases to 16 m/s?

The Sun is not the primary source of energy for which resource?
A oil
B tidal
C wind
D wave

Which list contains only vector quantities?
A acceleration, distance, speed
B electric field strength, momentum, weight
C energy, mass, temperature
D force, time, velocity
The graph shows how the velocity of an elevator varies with time. The elevator starts from the third floor of a tall building. When is the elevator on the third floor again?

An object of mass 1.0 kg is at rest on the Earth. An identical object is at rest on a planet with a gravitational field strength of twice that on the Earth. Which row correctly compares the object on the planet to the object on the Earth?
An engineer researched the density of different liquids being used as coolants. Which liquids rise to the surface when poured into water?
The diagram shows a car moving along a road. The force due to the engine is 1500 N and the total drag force is 200 N. What is the motion of the car?
A pair of cutters is used to cut a rope. Where should the rope be positioned and at which labelled points should the hands be positioned to produce the greatest cutting force?
An object has a mass of 20 kg. Its velocity changes from 6 m/s to 10 m/s. Which impulse has acted on the object?
Useful energy is obtained from different energy resources. Four examples of energy resources are listed. How many of these depend on radiation from the Sun?
A box of mass 2.0 kg slides down a slope. What is the decrease in gravitational potential energy stored as the box moves from P to Q?
The diagram shows the path of a long-jumper. Which graph shows how the store of kinetic energy and gravitational potential energy of the long-jumper vary with time between points P and R?
Two forces with magnitudes F1 and F2 act on an object at right angles to each other. What is the magnitude of the resultant force?
A boy cycles 8.0 km in 30 minutes and then walks 2.0 km in 15 minutes. What is his average speed?
A small, light ball is dropped from a tall building. Which graph shows how its speed changes with time?
Which statement about gravitational field strength is NOT correct?
Three liquids P, Q, and R do not mix. A block is dropped into the cylinder and comes to rest as shown. Which statement about the block’s density is correct?
A uniform beam is pivoted at its centre with forces F1 and F2 applied. Which row is correct for the moments?
Which expression can be used to determine the impulse on a tennis ball?
Which row shows the process by which energy is released in the Sun, transferred to Earth, and stored on Earth?
An object of mass 20 kg is taken up stairs through a height of 4.0 m. What is the increase in gravitational potential energy?
An electrician uses a lifting machine. Given time, height, mass, and motor power, what is the efficiency of the machine?

An elephant of weight 45 000 N stands with all four feet on the floor.
The average pressure on the floor due to the elephant foot in contact with it is 34 000 Pa.
What is the area of each foot of the elephant?

The diagram shows an object of mass m projected with speed v from P to Q on a cliff height h. The object does work W against air resistance.
What is the kinetic energy of the object when it reaches point Q?

The diagram shows a Sankey diagram for an electric drill.
What is the total wasted energy shown by the diagram?

A student uses a metre ruler to measure the length of a sheet of paper.
Which measurement is shown to the nearest millimetre?
A 0.2932 m  B 0.293 m  C 0.29 m  D 0.3 m

A rocket travels with an average speed of 6 km/s for 2 minutes.
What is the distance travelled by the rocket?
A 12 km  B 50 km  C 720 km  D 12,000 km

The diagram shows the vertical forces acting on a ball as it falls vertically through the air. The ball does not reach terminal velocity.
Which row describes what happens to the resultant force on the ball and what happens to the acceleration of the ball as it falls through the air?

A coconut falls from a palm tree. At X, it has just started falling. Y is the point just before it hits the ground.
What is the acceleration of the coconut at X? (Air resistance can be ignored.)

A car is driven round a bend in the road at a constant speed.
What is the direction of the resultant force on the car when it is going round the bend?

The diagram shows a drawbridge attached to a wall by a hinge at one end and a cable at the other. The drawbridge is in equilibrium.
Which arrow shows a possible direction for the force at the hinge?

Which equation gives the momentum change of an object?
A momentum change = area / force
B momentum change = force × distance
C momentum change = force × time / distance
D momentum change = force × time
Determine the distance d of the centre of the load from the zero end of the ruler, as shown in Fig. 1.2.
Describe a technique for ensuring that the ruler is as near as possible to being balanced.

Calculate the distance a of the centre of the load from the 50.0 cm mark, using a = (50.0 cm – d). Then calculate the distance b of the centre of the load from the pivot, using b = (position of pivot – d).
Plot a graph of a / cm (y-axis) against b / cm (x-axis) using the values in Table 1.1. Draw the best-fit straight line.
Determine the gradient G of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.
Calculate the mass M of the metre ruler using the equation M = k / (G – 1), where k = 25 g. Give an appropriate unit.
The student adds a small piece of modelling clay to one end of the metre ruler to balance it. Suggest if this is a suitable change for this experiment and explain your answer.
Define impulse.

Fig. 2.1 shows a rocket and its exhaust gases.
The exhaust gases are emitted from the rocket with a velocity of 1400 m/s and at a rate of 2800 kg/s.

Show that the force exerted on the rocket by the exhaust gases is 3900 kN.
State the equation you use.
Calculate the maximum mass that this force can lift from the ground. Ignore air resistance.
Describe the motion between t = 0.90 min and t = 2.9 min on the speed–time graph.

Another bus travels at a speed of 8.9 m/s. The brakes apply a constant force and the bus stops in a distance of 23 m. This bus has a mass of 18,000 kg.

Calculate the kinetic energy of the bus before the brakes are applied.
Calculate the force applied to stop the bus.
A student has a measuring cylinder containing water and also has a balance. Which of these could she use to find the volume of a small metal sphere?
The diagram shows a solid object on a flat surface, with two forces acting. What is the resultant force on the object?
A ball is falling towards the ground. Which energy transfer is taking place?
Which row contains one scalar quantity and one vector quantity?
The table gives data about four liquids, W, X, Y, and Z. Which liquid forms which layer when all are put in the same container?
A weightless beam is balanced on a pivot with forces P, Q, and R. Which equation is correct?
An object changes speed from +3.0 m/s to -4.0 m/s. What is the change in momentum?

Plan an experiment to investigate how one variable affects the size of the horizontal distance d that a metal ball travels through the air from a flexible track. 

Your plan should:
• state the one variable you have chosen to investigate
• list any additional apparatus needed to measure this variable
• explain how to do the experiment
• state the key variables to be kept constant
• draw a table, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (no readings needed)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion.
Record t in Table 1.1 (time for 20 oscillations).
Calculate the period T of the oscillations. Record your answer in Table 1.1.
Suggest how the procedure can be improved to increase the accuracy of the result.
Calculate a value k1 for the spring constant of the spring using k1 = 19.7 / T^2.
Measure L (length of the spring from Fig. 1.3).
Calculate the actual stretched length l of the spring. Record l in Table 1.2.
Plot a graph of l / cm (y-axis) against m / g (x-axis). Draw the best-fit line.
Calculate the gradient G of your line. Show all your working.
Calculate k2 using k2 = 1 / G.
Compare k1 and k2. State whether they can be considered equal within 10% and show calculation.

4 A student investigates the bending of composite strips of wood when they are loaded at one end.

Plan an experiment to investigate how much composite strips bend when they are loaded at one end. Fig. 4.2 shows the set-up the student uses.

In your plan:
• state the variable that you are testing
• list any additional apparatus that you would use
• explain briefly how to do the investigation
• state the key variables to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use your readings to reach a conclusion.

1(a) The student measures, and records in Table 1.1, the unstretched length l0 of the spring. He does not include the loops at the ends of the spring in the measurement. The value l0 is the length of the spring when the load L on the spring is 0.00 N.

Describe one technique you would use to obtain an accurate value for l0. Draw a diagram to illustrate your answer.
1(b) Calculate the extension e of the spring using the equation e = (l – l0) when L = 5.00 N. Record this value of e in Table 1.1.
1(c) Plot a graph of L / N (y-axis) against e / cm (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0). Draw the best-fit line.
1(d) Determine the gradient G of the graph. Show all your working and indicate on the graph the values you use.

1(e) G is numerically equal to the spring constant k.

Record the value of k to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment. Include the unit.

Child B moves 0.050 m further away from the pivot.
Explain why the seesaw rotates clockwise.

Child A puts on a backpack and the seesaw now balances.
Calculate the mass of the backpack.
Define impulse.

Explain how the rubber floor reduces injury to the child.
Use ideas about impulse, force, momentum and time in your answer.
Define deceleration.

The acceleration of free fall is 9.8 m / s².
Show that the time taken for the ball to reach height h is 1.4 s. Ignore the effect of air resistance.
Calculate h. Ignore the effect of air resistance.

The ball is dropped from the top of a tall building.
Describe and explain the motion of the ball as it falls. Consider the effect of air resistance in your answer.

A student drops a heavy ball from a vertical height of 1.8 m above the ground. The ball then falls to the ground. It does not bounce after hitting the ground.

(a) Describe the transfers of energy of the ball between stores from when the ball begins to fall to when it reaches the ground.
(b) Calculate the maximum speed of the ball. Ignore air resistance. Show your working.
(a) Define acceleration.

(b) A train has a total mass of 520 000 kg. The train accelerates at 1.1 m/s².
(i) Calculate the time taken for the train to increase its speed from 15 m/s to 28 m/s.
(ii) Calculate the force required to produce an acceleration of 1.1 m/s² for this train.

(iii) The train uses electric motors.
Explain why the force on the train due to the motors is greater than the value calculated in (ii).

A load is suspended from a thread. The vertical force on the thread due to the load is 0.75 N.

(a) Calculate the mass of the load.

Fig. 1.1 shows the load suspended from the thread.
A wire is attached to the load at point X and pulled horizontally to the right.
The tension in the horizontal wire is 1.2 N.
By drawing a scale diagram or by calculation, determine:
• the magnitude of the resultant of the force at X due to the load and due to the tension in the wire
• the direction of the resultant relative to the vertical direction.
Show your working.

Forces may produce changes in the size and the shape of an object.
State two other changes that forces may produce.
Calculate the speed at which trolley P moves to the left.
Calculate the kinetic energy of trolley Q when it moves at 0.36 m/s.
State the energy transfer that takes place as the spring expands.
Define acceleration.

The mass of the ball is 0.0075 kg.
Calculate the resultant force acting on the ball when it is accelerating downwards at 2.8 m/s².

Describe what happens to the acceleration between t = 0 and t = 0.040 s.
Explain why this happens.
By drawing a tangent on Fig. 1.2, determine a value for the acceleration of the ball at t = 0.010 s.

A student measures the volume of a small, irregularly shaped stone.
Which apparatus must be used?

A a ruler and a measuring cylinder containing water
B a measuring cylinder containing water only
C a ruler and an empty measuring cylinder
D a ruler only

Which quantity is a vector?

A electric field strength
B energy
C mass
D temperature

An athlete runs 2.4 km in 12 minutes.
What is the average speed of the athlete?

A 0.20 m/s B 3.3 m/s C 29 m/s D 200 m/s

The graph shows how the speed of a car changes during a period of 50 s.
Which row gives the car’s greatest acceleration and the car’s greatest deceleration?

Which statement about gravitational field strength g is correct?

A g = weight / mass
B g = mass × weight
C g is defined as the mass per unit force
D g is equal to the acceleration of free fall

Which property of an object cannot be changed by applying forces?

A mass
B shape
C speed
D volume

A small ball of mass 0.10 kg travels horizontally at a speed of 600 m/s. It strikes a stationary wooden block of mass 1.9 kg resting on a frictionless horizontal surface. The ball stays in the block.
What is the speed of the ball and the block immediately after the impact?

A 30 m/s B 32 m/s C 60 m/s D 130 m/s

An object taken underwater will be damaged if the total pressure acting on it is greater than 2.1 MPa.
What is the maximum depth that the object can be taken underwater before it breaks?
(atmospheric pressure = 101 000 Pa, density of water = 1000 kg/m³)

A 10.3 m B 204 m C 214 m D 225 m

A student wishes to measure accurately the volume of approximately 40 cm³ of water. She has two measuring cylinders, a larger one that can hold 100 cm³, and a smaller one that can hold 50 cm³. The water forms a meniscus where it touches the glass.

Which cylinder and which water level does the student use to ensure an accurate result?
A larger one bottom of meniscus
B larger one top of meniscus
C smaller one bottom of meniscus
D smaller one top of meniscus

The motion of an object is represented by the speed–time graph shown.

Which quantity is equal to the area under the graph?
A acceleration
B average speed
C distance travelled
D kinetic energy

An astronaut of mass 80 kg is standing on a planet with gravitational field strength g = 3.8 N/kg.

What is the weight of the astronaut on this planet?
A 780 N B 300 N C 210 N D 21 N

A sealed container of volume 2000 cm³ contains air at high pressure. The container is placed on a top-pan balance. The balance reads 200.00 g. All the air is removed by a vacuum pump and the balance reading changes to 196.00 g.

What was the density of the pressurised air?
A 0.00200 g/cm³ B 0.098 g/cm³ C 4.00 g/cm³ D 10.2 g/cm³

Each diagram shows three forces on a beam.

In which situation is it possible for the three forces shown to be in equilibrium?
Options: A B C D

A gymnast jumps down from a high piece of apparatus. She gradually bends her knees as she lands.

Which effect does this have?
A She will have a smaller change of momentum.
B She will lose less kinetic energy.
C She will exert a smaller impulse on the ground.
D She will experience a smaller force from the ground.

The table gives four energy resources and states whether the main source of energy for the resource is the Sun.

Which row is correct?
A geothermal yes
B oil no
C water held behind a dam yes
D wind no

The equation Δp = ρgΔh can be used for a liquid.

What is the meaning of the term ρ?
A pressure due to the liquid
B density of the liquid
C total pressure due to the liquid and the air above it
D density of an object placed in the liquid

What are the correct terms for each change of state?

liquid to solid — liquid to gas
A solidification condensation
B melting condensation
C solidification evaporation
D melting evaporation

Extremely small pollen grains in water are viewed through a microscope. The grains are seen to move continually and randomly.

What is the reason for this random movement?
A The grains are moved by randomly moving water molecules.
B The grains are moved by random convection currents in the water.
C The grains are moved by random rays of light reflecting off them.
D The grains are moved by the random motion of their own atoms.
In which row are quantities correctly categorised into scalar quantities and vector quantities?
Which name is given to the quantity of matter in an object?

A body is moved from place X to place Y where the gravitational field strength is different.
What happens to its mass and to its weight due to the move?

The mass of an object is 2.5 kg. The volume of the object is 480 cm³.
What is the density of the object?

Four objects each have two forces acting on them.
Which object is in equilibrium?

A ball of mass m falls vertically and hits a hard surface.
Its speed on hitting the surface is v₁.
It rebounds vertically upwards with speed v₂.
What is the change in momentum of the ball?

A stone is dropped from a tall tower and falls a distance of 50 m to the ground.
The stone has a mass of 3.0 kg.
At which speed does the stone hit the ground?

A coal-fired power station generates electricity. Coal is burned and the energy released is used to boil water. The steam from the water makes the generator move and this produces electricity.
Which row gives the name of the energy store in the coal and the energy store of the moving generator?

A man puts some ice into a glass of water on a warm day.
After a short time, he notices that the ice disappears and that water droplets appear on the outside of the glass.
Which two changes of state are taking place?

Gas of volume 200 cm³ is trapped inside a container by a piston.
The piston is pushed to the right and the volume of the gas decreases to 100 cm³.
The temperature of the gas remains constant.
Which row states the effect that this has on the kinetic energy of the gas particles and the force per unit area exerted by the particles colliding with the inside walls of the container?

Plan an experiment which will enable a student to investigate how the range of a ball depends on the angle at which it is launched.

The range is the horizontal distance that the ball travels after leaving the end of the flexible channel and before hitting the ground.

In your plan, you should:
• list any additional apparatus needed
• explain briefly how to do the experiment (you may add to Fig. 4.1 if it helps your explanation)
• state the key variables to keep constant
• draw a table with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the results to reach a conclusion.

A boat crosses a river. The boat points at right angles to the river bank and it travels at a speed of 3.5 m/s relative to the water. A river current acts at right angles to the direction the boat points. The river current has a speed of 2.5 m/s.

By drawing a scale diagram or by calculation, determine the speed and direction of the boat relative to the river bank.

Speed is a scalar quantity and velocity is a vector quantity.

State the names of one other scalar quantity and one other vector quantity.

The ship is made of steel. The density of steel is 7800 kg/m³ and the density of water is 1000 kg/m³.

Explain why the ship floats in the water.

The containers with the greatest mass are loaded near the bottom of the ship.

State and explain the effect on the stability of the ship of loading the containers in this way.

A crane lifts a container 48 m vertically upwards. The mass of the container is 30 000 kg.

Calculate the energy transferred to the gravitational potential energy stored in the container.
State the principle of conservation of energy.

A wind turbine has a maximum output power of 1.8 MW. The turbine operates at maximum power for 4.0 h.

Define the unit kW h.
Calculate the energy produced by the wind turbine operating at maximum power for 4.0 h. Give your answer in kW h.

Radiation from the Sun is the main source of energy for most of our energy resources.

State two energy resources that are not due to radiation from the Sun.
A machine has a power input of 200 W and a useful output energy of 1 kJ in 6 minutes. What is the efficiency of the machine?

What is the unit of power?
A joule
B newton
C volt
D watt
A rectangular block of weight 16 N is resting on a flat surface. What is the pressure at the base of the block due to its weight?
An oil tank has a base area of 2.5 m² and is filled with oil to a depth of 1.2 m. The density of the oil is 800 kg/m³. What is the force on the base due to the oil?
Which list contains two scalar quantities and two vector quantities?

The diagram shows the speed–time graph for a car.
Which row describes the motion of the car at point X and at point Y?

Four objects are moving in a straight line.
The table shows the distances moved by each object in each second of its motion.
Which object is moving with constant non-zero acceleration?

The drag force on a car increases with speed. At 20 m/s, the total drag force is 400 N. The mass of the car is 1200 kg and the driving force is constant at 700 N.
Which statement about the acceleration of the car at 20 m/s is correct?

A rectangular swimming pool is 50 m long and 25 m wide. It contains water at a depth of 2 m. The density of the water is 1000 kg/m³.
What is the mass of the water in the pool?

An object is rising vertically at constant speed through water. There are three vertical forces acting on it: the weight W, the drag force D, and the upward force U.
Which diagram shows the magnitude and direction of the vertical forces acting on the object?

Two boys of equal weight sit on one side of a see-saw. Their father, of weight 1000 N, sits on the other side. The see-saw is balanced and moves up and down. During one part of the cycle, the father descends through 40 cm. At the same time, the boy nearest the pivot rises through 20 cm, while the other boy rises through 80 cm. What is the weight of each boy?
